ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of theories behind what makes a good government.

I gained a deeper understanding of the political theories that have shaped and influenced the history of modern government. I also learned how to respectfully discuss arguments and ideas with my peers.
none
you can't wring the politics out of politics.

A strong knowledge of political philosophers from the enlightenment, anti-enlightenment, and democratic traditions. A good grasp on competing theories on individual liberties and distributive justice. Interesting discourse on the subject of political philosophy itself.
This course followed a focused application of philosophy on political theory through the past few centuries.
Lots of analytical skills and a greater understanding of political philosophy.
This course introduced me to key ideas and points of discussion raised by relevant philosophers.
Better understanding of history of ideas. Cursory understanding of A LOT of different thinkers. Better enabled to respond to political philosophy writ large.
I learned a lot about different political philosophers and the history of political philosophy
I learned about the fundamentals of political philosophy and can now talk with smart people on philosophical topics.

i learned about foundation of political theory and surveyed many political and economic theorists in this course. my biggest takeaway from the course is definitely the larger questions that it posed, such as "who gets to decide" or "how much reparations do we give"
Overview of various thinkers of political philosophies, as well as general periods/trends/progressions
I learned the basis of modern Western political philosophy.
I learned how to read political papers from many different times in history and extract their arguments. I also learned how to evaluate these ideas and argue for or against them.
Thinking about the nature of man, philosophy on how to distribute, Locke, Bentham, etc.
I had an introduction to political philosophy through many prominent thinkers starting from the utilitarian tradition up until today.

I learned the approaches and theories of many famous political philosophers, from the enlightenment thinkers like Locke, Kant, and John Stuart Mill, to the anti-enlightenment thinkers of the 20th century.

This course gave me a greater understanding of political philosophy and how we think about how the world is and ought to be. I learned multiple approaches to critical thinking and reasoning skills. Philosophers and theorists were introduced in a clear and concise way. I also appreciated that the course offered critiques and limitations of inidividual theorists.
Learned more about political philosophy... not really any new skills
Analytical observation of the US government/political system
I learned a lot about different branches in political philosophy and moved through many different thinkers and movements.
I was able to develop my knowledge surrounding past political ideologies and was able to argue its validity and practicality.
I learned about the major theorists and theories of the Western political philosophy tradition from the Enlightenment through contemporaries.

Knowledge of a broad swath of thinkers of political philosophy from the Enlightenment onwards. Skills to critically evaluate and put them in conversation with one another. Insights into how these topics have been thought about, discussed, debated and implemented at the highest levels.
I got to explore political philosophers and their theories in depth. I also became a better writer by focusing on highlighting my argument in both long essays.
A overarching understanding of major political thinkers

I learned a lot about political philosophy (the original political thinkers and what, in detail, they believed), but I also learned about philosophy as a general field, the way that it's taught and the type of content to be expected in a philosophy class.
Great understanding of both older and more modern political philosophers
understanding philosophy, morality, and politics rooted in the western tradition on a whole new level
This course provides you with a great overview of some important political philosophers.
I could think about politics with a philosophical lens.
I learned a lot about the basics of political philosophy and how to read more complex philosophical texts.
none
I learned how to closely read political theory and apply it to modern contexts.
I learned about how to analyze arguments from a moral and philosophical perspective.

Writing section improves your ability to understand and synthesize the writings of others that can be sometimes convoluted and complex as well as how to support and defend your arguments in a highly detailed manner
learned about classical/neoclassical utilitarianism, marxism, democracy, and other political philosophies

This was a really good survey course into utilitarianism, Marxism, social contract theory, and was an overall good introduction to political thought and moral philosophy. The writing credit was definitely helpful for me to better understand the philosophers and their school of thought, and without those papers, I think I definitely would not have been able to have had the understanding that I left the class with. You get exactly the amount of effort you put in, as the material can be quite dense and confusing, but Professor Shapiro's lectures are really helpful, and section gave me the opportunity to work through my thoughts.
I gained a basic understanding of different philosophies and the philosophers who championed these policies
I learned how to analyze the work of political philosophers and how to respond to their respective theories.
I learned about a wide range of philosphers.

This course was a fantastic introduction to political philosophy and the many forms that it comes in. I enjoyed the breadth of its coverage and felt that we were given adequate information to understand each of the main theories on a basic level.
I believe my writing skills greatly improved
Critical thinking, reading, explanation, presentation
Understanding and applying the ideas of basic political philosophers covered in the class, from the enlightenment to the anti-enlightenment and democracy.
You will be able to get an overview of ideas in political philosophy. The class also teaches you how to apply and write about these ideas.

I developed a broad understanding of ethics in politics and now have a deeper context for the political systems of the world. This class gave me both historical and philosophical insight into governmental systems and has deepened my thinking regarding ethics.
Introduction to political philosophy and thinking, focused on the Western canon
I learned how to deeply and critically analyze the thoughts of political thinkers and synthesize those musings in an effective way.
I learned about deep moral and rational thinking and how to approach more complex philosophical texts
Introductory political philosophy and politics skills.

I learned how to better read works of political philosophy, to be less intimidated by political philosophy as a discipline, how to discuss matters of political philosophy, and gained a much more complete understanding of the major works, trends, and advances in political philosophy.
I have a better understanding of where i stand politically
How to engage in discussion, read difficult philosophy and think about it
I learned a lot about the political thinkers and philosophy behind much of modern political thought (such as Marx with communism, Nozick with libertarianism, and Schumpeter with democratic theory)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: depending on your TF, discussion can be super interesting (Nica Siegel is incredible! But I think she's graduating this semester). Sometimes what you're learning is applicable to real life, and that's always a super cool moment.
Weaknesses: the readings are honestly super dense and difficult to understand.

The strengths of the class were that Professor Shapiro broke down complicated ideas in very simple ways. The class content was also manageable so that you don't have to have prior knowledge in the area.

weakness was the whole class. the lectures barely helped my understanding of the readings and thinkers because so often we'd just be hearing long quotes or random examples but this did not help. the readings were very long and tedious and didn't even need all that were assigned because they were barely all covered in lecture

strengths -  discussion sections, content 
weaknesses - it gets pretty monotonous during the week

The strength of the course is in the engagement with students and the real-life examples drawn into the course. I also thought the discussion sections were fairly interesting. At times, the readings didn't feel entirely applicable to the subjects addressed in class, but they were mostly interrelated.
The class is wonderful and there is always a high level of engagement from all the staff running the course. It is easy to get feedback and assistance on digesting the difficult political theory.

The virtual format was an overall weakness, but that couldnt be helped. The discussion section was a great way of keeping everyone engaged. A weakness would be communication at the beginning: I wish I knew which were writing intensive sections and which werent. (I accidentally signed up for a writing intensive section). Also, a strength were the TAs, who were very helpful throughout the class.
The course took advantage of online learning well. Professor Shapiro's lectures weren't too long, and he was great at synthesizing and explaining sometimes hard to understand readings and concepts.

Strengths: Great TFs and well organized course content.

Weaknesses: Was sometimes unclear when Prof. Shapiro was relaying the professional consensus vs. his own opinion. Also, the course kind of felt like it took an unexpected turn at the end to visit some of Shapiro's work.

The lectures were very interesting and the discussion sections helped a lot with understanding the concepts taught in lecture. The readings for this course were very long and often hard to understand, we were often assigned 50 pages in one night that could have been summarized in 3 pages.
Mofopo is a wonderful class which everyone should take to orient themselves in political philosophy.

strengths: i loved section, the TAs are very thoughtful and work hard to make this course engaging. professor shapiro's lectures were also quite interesting. 
weaknesses: tying in the reading more to the material. oftentimes, i would skip the readings and it wouldn't materially affect the way i engaged in class or section.

Strengths: always very engaging lectures, and fun discussion sections
Weaknesses: infrequent assessments, and not enough guidance on those assessments especially given that there were so few and far between. Also great amount of reading, some of which was not even addressed in lectures/included for assessments.

Strengths: Reading load was generally manageable, sections were helpful.

Weaknesses: Unclear expectations for the written exams, and while Professor Shapiro's lectures were engaging, it wasn't always clear how various schools of thought connected.

I think it is a relatively standard Yale course and you can get as much out as you put in. I learned a lot and am thankful for all the effort my TF and professor put into the course! This may not be the best course for you if you don't like the topics or if you dislike readings.

Strengths: this class was well facilitated for learning! 
Improvement: the content was sometimes not taught in lay mans terms

This course did not lend itself very well to the virtual format. While the TF-led sections were a plus every week, lectures were slow and not very engaging, coming from a PoliSci major, but this is in many ways a quintessential course for anyone interested in the subject matter, and I'm sure it will only improve in-person.
I think the lectures were very explanatory and the discussion sections complemented them perfectly.
Many of the readings were extremely dense and sometimes difficult to get through. A strength however, is that Shapiro was able to synthesize the readings in a clear way during his lectures.

This course was really fast-paced and because there was so much material on each person, it felt difficult to absorb at times. In the future I think it could be improved by focusing on fewer people but going deeper into each of their ideas. A strength of this course was the structure of lectures. I thought they were very straightforward and offered real world examples to help apply the concepts practically.
Lectures were structured in a very confusing way.

Strength: It was very pragmatic and most of the topics discussed were part of our everyday decision-making process.

Weakness: The virtual aspect did not readily provide effective interactions.

strengths: great selection of readings, the overall structure made sense and flowed from one lecture to the next 
weaknesses: the democracy section felt a bit rushed and scattered, I would have liked some more clarity and structure there.

strengths: Really enjoyed the lectures themselves. The professor usually cleared up any confusion from the text. 
weaknesses: Some of the readings were a bit dense. I wished that for some of them there could have been an outline for what to look for or put more of an emphasis on. I also wished that there was additional class time focused on synthesizing a particular idea or period rather than waiting till the end of the semester.

The course does cover the theorists effectively if more quickly than is helpful for deep understanding. The major weakness of the course, in my mind, is that, for students in non-Writing Intensive sections, there are only two assignments the entire semester: a midterm worth 30% of the grade and a final worth 50% of the grade; this does not allow for growth over the semester and places far too much pressure on these assignments.

The strength is how much it covers, and quite efficiently as well. It could be improved by providing more of a structure to the readings, and trying to connect the title of the course, and some main themes, with Shapiro's occasionally rambling discussion of the subject matter.
Great class. I would say that I wish the lectures were more clear and the sections had some sort of powerpoint prepared to go over key concepts.

The course was brilliantly structured - the professor was very clearly competent and so were the TAs. It was structured in the best way to facilitate student learning. I literally cannot think of one improvement.
The lectures were awesome. Shapiro is great to listen to and he makes it somewhat interactive. The readings can be a bit much but skipping some is totally ok.
Great introduction without too too much work. Not super in depth as its a survey course but definitely built my understanding of political philosophy.
The lectures were a bit boring, but Professor Shapiro did a great job giving an overview of different philosophers and their stances.
Discussion sections were great. Good powerpoints.

The course is great at getting you through a broad sweep of basic political philosophy without requiring any real background in the topic. A weakness would be that aside from the midterm/final, if you aren't in a writing section, I didn't feel like I got much practice or intermediate grades on writing about these thinkers which made the midterm and final more daunting.
Professor Shapiro is a great lecturer and made complicated concepts easier to understand. I appreciated the weekly discussion sections.
weakness - lectures were EXTREMELY slow...could hardly pay attention
I believe the course was strengthened by the discussion sections. However, I feel like the lecture slides were very hard to follow.

Strengths: Shapiro explains things really well and all the TAs were very engaged with their students, making sure we understood the material
Weaknesses: pretty sure every single thinker we went in-depth on was a white male, which was unfortunate

I enjoyed the course and learned a lot from it, but feel like could be more helpful if information was given in a straightforward manner rather than by always asking questions (especially in section) and by going more in depth on fewer topics rather than scratching the surface of many, especially later in the course.

Professor Shapiro is an incredible lecturer! It does cover a lot of material and some parts felt a bit rushed, but it is a good survey course as long as you're willing to put the time into the readings. It's easy to get overwhelmed with the readings and they can pile up, but missing one or two readings didn't really leave me in the dark since there were only 2 papers and a final (for the writing credit).
I got to learn a lot about the basics of political philosophy.

This class has the potential to be very interesting if you are deeply interested in political philosophical study. It is not as centered on politics as it is sometimes dense political theory. Professor Shapiro does a good job at simplifying this, though, as well as making it accessible.
weakness- lack of engagement. the course was not very collaborative

Strengths: learn lots of philosophers
Weakness: learning so many philosophers mean you don't really get to know one
I felt that there were too many philosophers covered during some sessions to the point where it made it difficult to discuss them all within the section time that we had.
The course was taught pretty well
Really interesting but sometimes the material was esoteric

Though it may be difficult given the large enrollment, having small assignments or reading quizzes to check our understanding of the content may have helpful, and make it so the midterm/final exams define our grade less.

The strengths was its content and lectures which were both very interesting and engaging. It was impressive how Professor Shapiro managed to generate discussion with 90+ students in the class. A weakness was the difficulty of some of the assignments. Its not easy to get an A on a paper, although its also not to hard to get a decent grade on one.

This course made good use of examples and dove deeply into thinkers for the first half of the semester. The second half was slightly more rushed and I for one struggled to keep up with the pacing at times.
Strengths are professor Shapiro and TA Da'Von Boyd
The course was very strong. The discussion sections were thought-provoking and engaging and the lectures were, too.

Strengths: passionate professor and TFs; availability of resources; fun discussion sections
Weaknesses: difficult to engage with the material virtually
Loved the discussion sections, felt like lectures were drained out and long, could have been just zoom.

The course assigned too much reading. This made it so that I promptly gave up on reading all the assigned materials every week and then soon after that gave up reading more than I needed to to answer the weekly reading responses mandated by my TA. That said, the material was interesting and important, and the readings were good, no doubt.
more engagement
I think a strength was the discussion sections, weakness was that there weren't a lot of assignments so each one mattered a lot

The greatest strength of the course is the discussion sections. Since the discussion sections are smaller (10-15 people), it allows for a lot of good substantive discussion about the material from our readings and lecture, giving us the opportunity to digest the material in our own terms. Discussion sections were really crucial in helping me understand some of the more difficult material in the class. The greatest weakness of the course are the readings. Some of the readings (especially some of the older ones) are a bit difficult to read and understand (because of the language and some missing context), and others are just very dry and/or technical, which makes getting through the readings and understanding them a little difficult at times. Some days also feature a lot more reading than others, which I feel like hinders my ability to understand all of the material from the texts that I've been made to read.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was one of the more engaging lectures this year, since Professor Shapiro asked poll questions and called on students.
The course translated well, and Professor Shapiro did a fantastic job teaching online.
Professor Shapiro facilitated discussion/questions in his lectures, and mandatory sections were excellent at facilitating discussion among students.
No problems, format worked great.
All of them succeeded
The course was well-adapted for the virtual format.
i would advocate for lectures to be mandatory.
Most things were great! I'm sure lectures would be even more engaging in person.
Live but recorded lectures were helpful in case you missed a day.

I think sections were really helpful because they were easier to pay attention to. personally, I found it difficult to pay attention to all the lecture courses I took this semester and I think that is an unavoidable consequence of online learning and definitely no fault of my professor.
Virtual section was run very smoothly; this class adjusted well to online

I appreciated the flexibility and consideration offered by TAs in the course with regard to assignments. It was also helpful that the live virtual lectures were recorded and posted to canvas. The course offered the ability to engage as much or as little as the students were comfortable with. There was not a significant amount of pressure to participate as there can be in other courses.
Nothing was really geared towards COVID specifically.

The Discussion sections were amazing. 
Area of improvement: There should be a 5-mins meditation before every virtual class.

The lecture allowed us to absorb the information while the discussion was great to flex our own muscles and use what we learned. Zoom was as effective as any method could have been given the pandemic.
the recorded lectures were very helpful. I usually watched them over again to prepare for the midterm or try to understand some of the content that went over my head.
It all worked fine, and it was nice to be able to rewatch lectures at will.
Good class overall to facilitate learning.
There were not many specific practices related to COVID that this class did, I imagine it was the same as taking an in-person political science class, but virtual.
Lectures were great and felt very personal. I thought that section could be a bit boring but some of it is just a function of classmates.
section was wonderful! i am so grateful to have had Polly as my TA
Recorded lectures were great. Readings were expensive.
asking students questions in lecture helped a lot
Basically perfect  sections allowed for engagement, while lectures conveyed the information.
Recorded lectures were very helpful in allowing me to take notes and follow the professor.
The reading responses we were assigned succeeded. I believe that the lecture slides could have been better made to be simple and break down the argument of the thinkers.
section and office hours were really well-done -- my TF was very approachable and created a safe learning environment
I definitely think that this class would be improved through in-person learning.

I felt like because of COVID the lectures had less engagement than they would have in real time. This is to no fault of anyone, however, as Professor Shapiro did his best to maintain attention. Section was very engaged.
The live lecture felt isolating at times. (very little room for engagement)
Sections were successful as they convinced us all to speak
It was well adapted to online learning
Discussion sections were great, helped cement material
Lectures supplemented by discussion sections worked well.
I thought the inclusion of discussion was a good thing to have in the lectures.

This course adapted fairly well to the pandemic. The lectures had some student engagement and were recorded for convenience and accessibility. Sections met as virtual seminars which felt fairly similar to standards sections.
The virtual format in general was difficult, but sections were always helpful. There should be more reflection posts to engage with the material.

I thought there was a good effort made to improve learning conditions and accommodate students. That said I think more could have been done to keep us engaged and aid our understanding of the material (and the teacher's understanding of our concerns).
Discussion sections because it actually provided some interaction.
The professors hanging around after class to chat with students and answer questions was great and lessened the feeling of anonymity induced by Zoom.
more interactive shit

Success: recording lectures
Improvement: Would have helped to have the lecture slides before the lectures

The lectures were relatively engaging, with a decent amount of interaction between the professor and students. I think the virtual discussion sections worked great, since there ended up being a lot of good, substantive conversations that allowed me to better digest the course material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it! It was super interesting and not too difficult.
not at all
sure
Yes! I took the writing intensive version of this course and really enjoyed engaging with other students and my teaching fellow on such interesting material.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. However, I would make sure people are open to learning philosophy beforehand. Philosophy can be intense and getting thrown into it can be hard.
Yes. I think its a great philosophy course  and teaches you to think differently about your argumentation.

I would recommend this course to somebody wanting an introductory understanding of moral philosophy. Although the reading can be a bit much, Professor Shapiro is a great lecturer, the midterm and final are reasonable assesments, and TAs/Sections are great and engaging.

Yes, especially if you're not a poli sci or philosophy major but are interested in political philosophy. Great course for just getting a taste of everything without any expectation of prior knowledge.
Yes, if they are interested in learning about political science then take it, otherwise look somewhere else.
A wonderful course for all majors.

yes! i would recommend this course to people who want a low workload survey into the realm of political theory and to understand the different eras of philosophers and how that fits into a larger picture.
Good introductory political science course
Absolutely! If interested in any sort of political thinking, a great starter!
It is a solid foundational course so I would recommend it.

If you find the topics interesting or need to take the course I would absolutely recommend this course! I think you can get through it without too much effort however, if you do try and do the readings you will learn a lot!
Yes!
Sure, the subject is pretty interesting and you get to learn from a renowned political scientist in Professor Shapiro.
I would definitely recommend this course to students who want to learn more about political philosophy.
If the student is interested in political philosophy, then absolutely.

Yes I would! It fulfills the political philosophy requirement for the political science major, so I would recommend it if other students need that. But I also think is a great introduction to political philosophy and is enjoyable subject matter that challenges students' conceptions of the world. Professor Shapiro is really engaging and clearly so passionate about the subject matter!
Not really. I think it was taught in a very confusing way.
Yes, because it is a great introductory class for majoring in Political Science.

I would recommend this course to anyone looking for a good, solid overview of some of the most influential thinkers in political philosophy. It is geared towards beginners, which is great because you can take the class without intimidation.
Yes I would. It provided a clear and well-thought-out introduction to political philosophy, and I left the class feeling prepared to engage in similar topics in the future.

Yes, depending on what you hope/need to get out of it. Definitely if you want to dip your toes into the (often frustrating) world of political philosophy, go for it. If you need it for EP&E, go for it also. If you really like reading the works of old white guys but were scared of commitment to DS, go for it as well. But if you are more interested in going deep, in really understanding any one of these thinkers, or like the practical aspects of political science, the questions with answers...maybe not. What I will say is that it seemed like the non writing-intensive folks had a blast, and I will say that with almost certainty. All you really had to do (at least this year) was pay somewhat attention during lecture/section and put effort towards the midterm and final.
Yes! Great course. Lots of concepts explored that are relatable to many other courses.

Absolutely! If you are even remotely interested in studying or majoring in Philosophy and/or Political Science, this is a must-take. Note that there is a Coursera version of this course and the material is still introductorythere might be more specialized course you would be interested in as well.

I would recommend this course to another student - only if that student has enough college experience to actually keep themselves on track for the class. It was very easy to fall behind, because there were no real assignments for the class, so you could easily fall behind on readings and lectures and you need to remain responsible for that. But the course's content was interesting, and it was organized well, so I'd suggest it to another student.
Absolutely. A great writing credit for those who dont feel like doing an English class.
absolutelyvery important to understanding the moral foundations of the government in the world to this day
Yes! A great way to fulfill the EP&E req, interesting and not terribly difficult if you keep up with the readings / lectures (although you can get away with skimming some of the readings if needed).

Yes! If you want to get a broad overview of a lot of really important thinkers, this is a great course. You definitely get as much or as little as you put in, so doing all the readings, going to lecture, etc will set you up for success.
Yes, if they like philosophy and politics
If you're marginally interested in philosophy and politics, sure, this is a great introduction.

If you have never taken political philosophy before, and would like a very well organized primer on the topic, this course is fantastic. Not a philosophy or PLSC major, and I found the class very approachable a good way to learn without dying in mountains of work.

Yes, if you are interested in political philosophy. It is something of a survey class, so some of the conclusions drawn from each philosopher feel shallow and oversimplified, but the class itself is interesting enough regardless.  However, the structure of assignments provided very little incentive to keep up with the readings or class lectures.
This class is a very basic intro to political philosophy course so if your major requires that you take it obviously take it.
Yes, everything I learned was taught well and was interesting. This course was challenging for me but also very engaging.
Yes, this course was a great intro to political philosophy that takes an interesting approach to analyze moral arguments of real-world issues!
Definitely! Great class to satisfy the political philosophy requirement in the poli sci major, or that of the one in the EP&E major. Also good for a writing credit.
Yes if you're interested in political philosophy and willing to do the reading

I would recommend this class as a good introduction to moral philosophy and politics. It's a good foundational/survey course for anyone who's interested. It felt like a very low-commitment class that didn't actually have that much writing for a writing credit.
Yes, if you are really interested in getting a crash course in political philosophy.
It's a good writing credit and if you want a basic overview of lots of political philosophy, go for it. If you're more interested in politics, take something else.
I would recommend this course for the writing-intensive credit.
Yes This is an enjoyable class. Not my favorite class but I think that happen in larger intro courses.
I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in political philosophy.
Yes
Yes, if interested in philosophy
I recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning the basics of political philosophy, but its redundant if youve taken higher level courses.
For those interested in the basics of different political philosophers, this course is a good take and little background is required.
Yes. The course was great, just be prepared to do a lot of readings.

I would, dependent on their interest level in the material. As a non-major, it gave me base level insights into different areas of thought without getting too entrenched in details. It moves quickly and does not go in depth in certain areas, but as a survey course it is quite effective.
Yes, for anyone who needs an introduction to political philosophy.
Yes, I'd say it's a must for anyone interested in political philosophy and thought.

Know that this is a deeply philosophical course  while it is certainly tied to modern government, that is not the focus. This is a class that requires deep thinking and attention. I feel like I did not understand that going in and was frustrated when my expectations were not met. That said I would recommend this course if that is what you are looking for and enjoy.
Not really, don't personally like philosophy, doesn't seem like a good representation of a PLSC major.

I would not. I think the course is simply too much reading and too much information shoved at you all at once for any one to really retain or internalize any of it. For students really looking to attend political philosophy boot camp, perhaps I would recommend the course, but only if they are truly committed to devoting a huge chunk of their time each week to learning the material.
yes
Yes, it made me think a lot !

Depends. If you are planning on a major in political science or any other field related to politics, then this class is probably a good one to take since it gives you a lot of context behind much of modern political thought. However, if you are not planning on majoring in these fields, then it really depends on your level of interest in political philosophy. I was more interested in the politics aspect of the course versus the philosophy portion, so I wasn't all that engaged with the material taught in the course, although it was still overall pretty interesting to learn. The class is also a nice WR credit for anyone who needs one.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion.
We had live virtual lectures in addition to weekly discussion sections.
Section discussions, which took the format of a virtual seminar
live lecture and discussion section
Also had weekly discussion sections.
discussion section once a week
discussion section
Weekly discussion sections.
Lecture that was also recorded and had a mandatory l discussion section.
Live virtual section
Live virtual lecture (that was also recorded) and virtual discussion sections.
Live lecture + weekly discussion sections
recorded live virtual lecture + discussion section
Live lecture and live discussion sections
recorded zoom lecture + mandatory section
Also virtual discussion sections!
Live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section
We had two live lectures that were recorded and one live section a week.
Live virtual lectures and live virtual discussion sections.
Sections with TF
N/A
live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
Live discussion sections
As well as a weekly section. I also took it as a writing section.
Only live virtual lecture
Weekly virtual seminars with TF's
The lectures were live but also recorded.
Virtual sections.
section weekly
With weekly discussion section
virtual discussion
live lecture with a zoom section
Virtual discussion
Discussion section
and live discussion sections
Weekly synchronous sections.
We had live virtual lectures and discussion sections.
recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Weekly section.
Though the class was a live virtual lecture, I watched it asynchronously.
lectures were recorded and sections were synchronous and virtual
The class utilized a combination of weekly live virtual lectures and live virtual sections.
Recorded and live lectures, live section
section
Virtual lection and virtual session
With discussion section
Discussion section
Weekly discussion section.
Discussion section.
We had virtual lectures twice a week and met weekly in a virtual section.
Discussion section as well
Weekly synchronous section
recorded lecture; live virtual discussion section
Discussion sections as well.
Love virtual section.

live lecture 
online resources
I rewatche dsthe lectures several times
live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section
